elements.content: Tailoring the microstructure of a selective layer is a highly attractive way to improve the water flux of a reverse osmosis (RO) membrane by forming a crumpled surface without altering its chemical structure required for high salt rejection. However, it is challenging to maintain its structural integrity and stability and high flux at high pressure during desalination. Herein, a robust hilly thin-film composite (TFC) polyamide (PA) membrane is developed based on composite substrates made of cellulose nanofibers (CNFs) and metal–organic frameworks (MOFs). Water-stable, highly crystalline, submicrometer-sized MOF crystals, NH2-MIL-53­(Al), are integrated with CNFs to form a robust and highly porous intermediate layer for the formation of a hilly PA layer. The resulting TFC RO membrane exhibits an excellent water permeance of 5.55 LMH/bar and a NaCl rejection of ∼94.8%. The strategy reported here has great potential for the fabrication of polyamide desalination membranes with enhanced flux and mechanical stability.

elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The supply of affordable and potable water remains a global challenge. The growing imbalance between freshwater supply and usage has led to greater reliance on water desalination technologies as a means of supplying freshwater. Membrane separation technology has become increasingly important for water purification, due to its low energy requirement and easy operation. The reverse osmosis (RO) desalination process is currently the most widely adopted technology. Current state-of-the-art RO membranes are thin-film composite (TFC) membranes composed of an interfacially polymerized polyamide (PA) selective layer on top of a porous support layer. Although significant efforts have been made to improve the properties of TFC membranes over the last decades, simultaneously achieving high water permeance and salt rejection remains a significant challenge. High water permeance and salt rejection in membranes are highly desirable for reducing the energy consumption and operating costs of the membrane desalination process.

elements.content: The PA selective layer, which is formed by interfacial polymerization, governs the water permeance and salt selectivity of the TFC membranes. Thus, it is imperative to control the formation of the PA layer to achieve desirable molecular and structural characteristics. Approaches such as the incorporation of porous nanoparticles into the PA layer and surface modification on the PA layer have been used to enhance the water permeance of the selective layer of the TFC membranes. However, it has proven difficult to achieve significant improvement of transport properties in the selective layers due to the limitation imparted by the highly cross-linked polyamide chains.
elements.clean_text: The PA selective layer, which is formed by interfacial polymerization, governs the water permeance and salt selectivity of the TFC membranes. Thus, it is imperative to control the formation of the PA layer to achieve desirable molecular and structural characteristics. Approaches such as the incorporation of porous nanoparticles into the PA layer and surface modification on the PA layer have been used to enhance the water permeance of the selective layer of the TFC membranes. However, it has proven difficult to achieve significant improvement of transport properties in the selective layers due to the limitation imparted by the highly cross-linked polyamide chains.

elements.content: Another strategy to increase the membrane permeance is to increase the surface area of the PA selective layer without compromising its salt selectivity. Wang et al. prepared a high permeance PA membrane by preloading sacrificial polydopamine-decorated ZIF-8 nanoparticles (PD/ZIF-8) on the porous support layer that were subsequently washed away, creating a more crumpled PA layer with an increased surface area. Compared to the PA active layer produced without PD/ZIF-8, the actual surface area of the PA layer with a PD/ZIF-8 loading of 4.3 μg/cm2 increased by 27 μm2 per projected area, resulting in a flux increase from ∼32.5 to 53.5 L/(m2 h bar) and a decline in Na2SO4 rejection from ∼99 to 95.3%. In a separate work, Zhang and co-workers created a PA layer with the Turing structure by manipulating the diffusion rates of PA monomers to significantly increase its surface area. The surface area increase of the membrane with striped (TS-II) Turing structures was nearly 2 times greater than that of the membrane with spotted (TS-I) structure. The water flux of TS-II reached 26.0 L/(m2 h bar), which was also approximately 2 times greater than that of TS-I. This result correlated well with the increased surface area ratio of the membranes. Wang and co-workers also reported the preparation of a highly permeable PA layer by introducing a scaffolding interlayer of covalent organic framework (COF) nanofibers in between the PA layer and the substrate. The rugged COF nanofiber layer increased the surface area of the PA layer, which contributed to increased water permeance. Arising from the ultrathin PA layer and increased surface area, the membranes showed a flux of as high as 31.1 L/(m2 h bar) and a Na2SO4 rejection of 95%. These studies demonstrate that increasing the surface area of the PA layer is an effective way to improve the water permeance of PA membranes. However, to the best of our knowledge, the approach has only been able to produce, at most, nanofiltration membranes but not RO membranes with higher salt rejections.

elements.content: Herein, we report on the fabrication of a polyamide TFC RO membrane with increased surface area using the cellulose nanofiber (CNF)- or NH2-MIL-53­(Al) metal–organic framework (MOF) nanoparticle-modified Nylon substrate. The Nylon membrane has suitable hydrophilicity and high mechanical strength, which make it an excellent substrate to fabricate high-performance TFC membranes. In this work, we chose both CNFs and NH2-MIL-53­(Al) particles to modify the Nylon substrate. The CNF-modified Nylon membrane serves as a highly porous and hydrophilic substrate, and water-stable, submicron-sized NH2-MIL-53­(Al) crystals that are permeable to water are used to create a hilly surface morphology. The resulting CNF/NH2-MIL-53­(Al) PA membrane exhibits a high water permeance of up to 5.55 L/(m2 h bar) while achieving a high NaCl rejection of 94.8%. This strategy has great potential to be implemented for the fabrication of desalination membranes with enhanced flux.
elements.clean_text: Herein, we report on the fabrication of a polyamide TFC RO membrane with increased surface area using the cellulose nanofiber (CNF)- or NH2-MIL-53(Al) metal-organic framework (MOF) nanoparticle-modified Nylon substrate. The Nylon membrane has suitable hydrophilicity and high mechanical strength, which make it an excellent substrate to fabricate high-performance TFC membranes. In this work, we chose both CNFs and NH2-MIL-53(Al) particles to modify the Nylon substrate. The CNF-modified Nylon membrane serves as a highly porous and hydrophilic substrate, and water-stable, submicron-sized NH2-MIL-53(Al) crystals that are permeable to water are used to create a hilly surface morphology. The resulting CNF/NH2-MIL-53(Al) PA membrane exhibits a high water permeance of up to 5.55 L/(m2 h bar) while achieving a high NaCl rejection of 94.8%. This strategy has great potential to be implemented for the fabrication of desalination membranes with enhanced flux.

elements.content: A rough and porous substrate is essential to achieving the hilly PA selective top layers. Ultrafine CNFs blended with submicron NH2-MIL-53­(Al) were coated onto the Nylon substrate (a pore size of 100 nm) to modify the surface of the Nylon substrate by a simple vacuum filtration method to reduce its pore size while maintaining its surface roughness for effective interfacial polymerization. Compared to conventional TFC substrates such as polysulfone, the Nylon substrate used in this study has larger pore sizes and thus lower water transport resistance. The fabrication of the hilly PA membrane on the CNF/NH2-MIL-53­(Al) substrate is illustrated in .
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Fabrication of the CNF/NH2-MIL-53(Al) Substrate

A rough and porous substrate is essential to achieving the hilly PA selective top layers. Ultrafine CNFs blended with submicron NH2-MIL-53(Al) were coated onto the Nylon substrate (a pore size of 100 nm) to modify the surface of the Nylon substrate by a simple vacuum filtration method to reduce its pore size while maintaining its surface roughness for effective interfacial polymerization. Compared to conventional TFC substrates such as polysulfone, the Nylon substrate used in this study has larger pore sizes and thus lower water transport resistance. The fabrication of the hilly PA membrane on the CNF/NH2-MIL-53(Al) substrate is illustrated in .

elements.clean_text: 1  Schematic Representation of the Fabrication of the Hilly PA RO Membrane on the CNF/NH2-MIL-53(Al) Substrate in Comparison with the Traditional Route of the Fabrication of the RO Membrane

elements.content: We investigated the sizes of CNFs and NH2-MIL-53­(Al) synthesized in the laboratory to ensure good compatibility. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) imaging revealed that the length and diameter of CNFs were 250–550 and 3–10 nm, respectively (Figure S1a,b in the Supporting Information), while NH2-MIL-53­(Al) particles of 300–700 nm in size were confirmed using the dynamic light scattering technique (a,b). Due to the adequate functional groups on the surface of CNFs (i.e., −OH, −COOH, and −CHO group), NH2-MIL-53­(Al) particles were fully wrapped in CNFs (c). The diffraction pattern of the synthesized NH2-MIL-53­(Al) matched well with the simulated X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of NH2-MIL-53­(Al) (d). NH2-MIL-53­(Al) contains one-dimensional shaped apertures (diameter ∼7.5 Å) with free NH2 groups, which can react with the abundant −COOH and −CHO groups of CNFs via a simple heating step. The ultrafine CNFs blended with the submicrometer size MOF crystals, NH2-MIL-53­(Al), were coated onto the Nylon substrate to reduce its pore size to meet the conditions for effective interfacial polymerization while increasing the roughness of the CNF/MOF substrate. Meanwhile, the NH2 groups of the NH2-MIL-53­(Al) MOF may react with TMC during the interfacial polymerization process, further stabilizing the PA layer. NH2-MIL-53­(Al) particles are highly stable in water as evidenced by the unchanged morphology of NH2-MIL-53­(Al) after being dispersed and kept in water for 10 months (Figure S1c in the Supporting Information).

elements.content: The morphologies of Nylon and CNF/NH2-MIL-53 loaded substrate membranes were investigated by SEM (a and S2 in the Supporting Information). The MOF loading on the Nylon substrate was varied at 0, 2, 4, and 8 μg/cm2, with the same CNF loading of 80 μm/cm2. The resulting substrates were denoted CM0, CM2, CM4, and CM8, respectively. The pore size of the pure Nylon substrate (Figure S2a in the Supporting Information) varies with some pores significantly larger than 100 nm. After the modification with CNF/NH2-MIL-53­(Al), the CNF/NH2-MIL-53­(Al) loaded substrate membranes (Figure S2b–e in the Supporting Information) show smaller pore sizes than the pure Nylon substrate. As the loading of NH2-MIL-53­(Al) increases, more NH2-MIL-53­(Al) cubic particles are observed on the surface of the substrate.

elements.content: The TFC PA membranes were fabricated by performing interfacial polymerization reactions on the Nylon and CNF/NH2-MIL-53­(Al) substrates. After the interfacial polymerization, a very thin layer of PA was formed on the rugged CNF/NH2-MIL-53­(Al) substrate. The cross-sectional SEM images of TFC-CM4 (an MOF loading of 4 μg/cm2) are shown in b and S3 (Supporting Information). The thickness of the PA layer is ∼23 ± 5 nm (the yellow numbers labeled in b), and the whole PA layer is continuous and rugged. Under the PA layer, the NH2-MIL-53­(Al) particles can be observed (b and S3d in the Supporting Information). A similar surface morphology is also observed in the TFC-CM2 and TFC-CM8 membranes (Figure S3c,e, Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text:
Characterization of the Hilly TFC RO Membrane on the CNF/NH2-MIL-53(Al) Substrate

The TFC PA membranes were fabricated by performing interfacial polymerization reactions on the Nylon and CNF/NH2-MIL-53(Al) substrates. After the interfacial polymerization, a very thin layer of PA was formed on the rugged CNF/NH2-MIL-53(Al) substrate. The cross-sectional SEM images of TFC-CM4 (an MOF loading of 4 μg/cm2) are shown in b and S3 (Supporting Information). The thickness of the PA layer is ~23 ± 5 nm (the yellow numbers labeled in b), and the whole PA layer is continuous and rugged. Under the PA layer, the NH2-MIL-53(Al) particles can be observed (b and S3d in the Supporting Information). A similar surface morphology is also observed in the TFC-CM2 and TFC-CM8 membranes (Figure S3c,e, Supporting Information).

elements.content: The SEM image of the surface of the TFC-CM membrane reveals the typical “ridge and valley” surface morphology of the PA membrane as well as regions of hilly structures (c and S4 in the Supporting Information). To identify whether these hilly structures are produced by the NH2-MIL-53­(Al) crystals, EDS mapping analyses were performed. As shown in d, the enriched area of the Al (red) element of NH2-MIL-53­(Al) matches well with the hilly structures of the surface of the TFC-CM4 membrane, confirming that most of the large hilly structures of the PA layer are formed by the underlying NH2-MIL-53­(Al) crystals. The observation is similar for all other TFC membranes (Figure S4 in the Supporting Information). The surface SEM and EDS mapping (c,d and S4 in the Supporting Information) results suggest that the hilly structures of PA layers are generated by the loading of NH2-MIL-53­(Al) in the substrate.

To identify whether these hilly structures are produced by the NH2-MIL-53(Al) crystals, EDS mapping analyses were performed. As shown in d, the enriched area of the Al (red) element of NH2-MIL-53(Al) matches well with the hilly structures of the surface of the TFC-CM4 membrane, confirming that most of the large hilly structures of the PA layer are formed by the underlying NH2-MIL-53(Al) crystals. The observation is similar for all other TFC membranes (Figure S4 in the Supporting Information). The surface SEM and EDS mapping (c,d and S4 in the Supporting Information) results suggest that the hilly structures of PA layers are generated by the loading of NH2-MIL-53(Al) in the substrate.

elements.content: Both TFC-Nylon and TFC-CM0 membranes exhibit relatively smooth surfaces (Figure S4a,b in the Supporting Information), whereas the morphologies of the PA active layers (Figure S4c–e in the Supporting Information) fabricated on CNF/NH2-MIL-53­(Al) substrates show more hilly structures. This is consistent with the EDS mapping, where more Al element signals are observed as the MOF loading increases (Figure S4f–j in the Supporting Information). The morphology of TFC-CM membranes is also confirmed by the AFM images, whereas the TFC membranes exhibit a typical ridge and valley structure (e and S5 in the Supporting Information). As shown in the low-magnification SEM images of the TFC membranes (Figure S6 in the Supporting Information), the PA membranes based on the pristine Nylon substrate (Figure S6a in the Supporting Information) also show similar hilly structures caused by the rough texture of the Nylon substrate, but the NH2-MIL-53­(Al) crystals, especially at higher loading, play a more significant role in achieving the hilly structures (Figure S6b–e in the Supporting Information).

This is consistent with the EDS mapping, where more Al element signals are observed as the MOF loading increases (Figure S4f-j in the Supporting Information). The morphology of TFC-CM membranes is also confirmed by the AFM images, whereas the TFC membranes exhibit a typical ridge and valley structure (e and S5 in the Supporting Information). As shown in the low-magnification SEM images of the TFC membranes (Figure S6 in the Supporting Information), the PA membranes based on the pristine Nylon substrate (Figure S6a in the Supporting Information) also show similar hilly structures caused by the rough texture of the Nylon substrate, but the NH2-MIL-53(Al) crystals, especially at higher loading, play a more significant role in achieving the hilly structures (Figure S6b-e in the Supporting Information).

elements.content: The attenuated total reflection-Fourier transform infrared (ATR-FTIR) spectra of the Nylon substrate, CM4 substrate, TFC-Nylon, and TFC-CM4 membranes are presented in a. All samples exhibit similar peaks of the Nylon substrate. The PA layer can be identified by the characteristic peaks of PA at 1686 and 1656 cm–1, corresponding to the CO stretching and C–N stretching (amide I band), respectively, as shown in both the TFC-Nylon and TFC-CM4 membranes. Compared to the TFC-Nylon membrane, TFC-CM4 shows an additional smaller peak at 1440 cm–1, which can be assigned to NH2-MIL-53­(Al) particles (Figure S1din the Supporting Information). The same peak is also observed in the CM4 substrate, which also consists of the NH2-MIL-53­(Al) particles, CNFs, and Nylon. The FTIR spectra further confirm the formation of the PA layer and the existence of NH2-MIL-53­(Al) in the CM4 substrate and the TFC-CM4 membrane, which is consistent with the evidence from SEM and EDS mappings (c,d and S4 in the Supporting Information).

elements.content: The surface wettability is a key factor affecting the permeability of the membrane. As shown in b, the average contact angles of all TFC-CM membranes are smaller than that of the TFC-Nylon membrane, indicating that the TFC-CM membranes are more hydrophilic. With CNFs and NH2-MIL-53­(Al) loaded on the substrate, the contact angle of the PA membrane decreases from 48.0° (TFC-Nylon) to 32.8° (TFC-CM4). The improved hydrophilicity of the TFC membranes may be contributed by the hydroxyl group of the CNFs and NH2-MIL-53­(Al) particles in the PA layer and the increased roughness. The contact angles of the TFC-CM membranes are much lower than that of the commercial membrane (DOW BW30). It has been previously reported that embedding the hydrophilic particles improves the hydrophilicity and thus the water flux of TFC membranes. Based on the contact angle results, a higher water flux of the TFC-CM membranes would be expected.

elements.content: The surface area and the roughness of the TFC membranes were investigated using AFM (c and S5 in the Supporting Information). Compare to the TFC-Nylon membrane, TFC membranes prepared on the CNF/NH2-MIL-53­(Al) substrate show much greater average (R a) and root-mean-square (R q) roughness values (c). The roughness values of the membranes increase with increasing the loading of the NH2-MIL-53­(Al) particles. An increase in the roughness value may lead to increased surface area favoring water transport, which may contribute to the increased water flux. The actual surface areas of TFC membranes with different mass loadings of NH2-MIL-53­(Al) and the commercial TFC membrane (DOW BW30) were calculated using AFM software (d). In this experiment, the projected area of each sample is the same, i.e., 25 μm2 (5 μm × 5 μm). The actual surface area of the TFC membranes is higher due to increased surface roughness, ranging from 35.4 to 62.3 μm2. As the loading of NH2-MIL-53­(Al) particles increases, the actual surface area of the PA membranes also increases. However, when the amount of NH2-MIL-53­(Al) particles is increased to 8 μg/cm2, the surface area of the TFC-CM8 membrane decreases slightly. This may be due to the agglomeration of NH2-MIL-53­(Al) particles on the surface of the CM8 substrate membrane, as shown in the SEM image (Figure S2e in the Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text: The surface area and the roughness of the TFC membranes were investigated using AFM (c and S5 in the Supporting Information). Compare to the TFC-Nylon membrane, TFC membranes prepared on the CNF/NH2-MIL-53(Al) substrate show much greater average (R a) and root-mean-square (R q) roughness values (c). The roughness values of the membranes increase with increasing the loading of the NH2-MIL-53(Al) particles. An increase in the roughness value may lead to increased surface area favoring water transport, which may contribute to the increased water flux. The actual surface areas of TFC membranes with different mass loadings of NH2-MIL-53(Al) and the commercial TFC membrane (DOW BW30) were calculated using AFM software (d). In this experiment, the projected area of each sample is the same, i.e., 25 μm2 (5 μm × 5 μm). The actual surface area of the TFC membranes is higher due to increased surface roughness, ranging from 35.4 to 62.3 μm2. As the loading of NH2-MIL-53(Al) particles increases, the actual surface area of the PA membranes also increases. However, when the amount of NH2-MIL-53(Al) particles is increased to 8 μg/cm2, the surface area of the TFC-CM8 membrane decreases slightly. This may be due to the agglomeration of NH2-MIL-53(Al) particles on the surface of the CM8 substrate membrane, as shown in the SEM image (Figure S2e in the Supporting Information).

elements.content: The effect of CNFs and the NH2-MIL-53­(Al) loading on the membrane desalination performance is shown in a. Without the CNF modification, the pore size of the pure Nylon substrate (Figure S2a in the Supporting Information) is larger than 100 nm, which is not suitable for preparing a TFC RO membrane. Therefore, TFC-Nylon shows almost no rejection of NaCl and the water flux is up to 300 LMH/bar. Normally, the pore sizes of the substrate for TFC RO membranes are mostly in the range of 5–70 nm. The CNF-modified substrate has a smaller pore size (66.7 ± 16.8 nm) (Figure S2b in the Supporting Information), and the corresponding TFC-CM0 membrane shows a reasonable NaCl rejection of 88.3% and a permeance of 4 LMH/bar. CNFs have previously been used as an intermediate layer for the PAN substrate in the fabrication of TFC NF/RO membranes by interfacial polymerization. The PA layer formed on the CNF substrate contained interconnected CNFs imbedded in the PA matrix. It was found that the interfacial gaps between CNFs and PA could act as water channels to improve the TFC membrane flux. Our approach to the incorporation of NH2-MIL-53­(Al) into the substrate further helped to improve the NaCl rejection of PA membranes. One of the reasons is that the addition of NH2-MIL-53­(Al) particles can cover the large pores of the Nylon substrate (Figure S2a in the Supporting Information) to reduce the subsequent defects of the PA layer of the TFC membranes. Another reason may be that the additional −NH2 groups of the NH2-MIL-53­(Al) particles and the −OH groups of CNFs react with TMC, thereby improving the cross-linking degree of the selective layer of TFC membranes. The TFC-CM0 membrane without the NH2-MIL-53­(Al) particles shows a water permeance of 4.19 LMH/bar and a NaCl rejection of 88.3%. At an optimal NH2-MIL-53­(Al) loading of 4 μg/cm2, the TFC-CM4 membrane exhibits much higher water permeance, up to 5.55 LMH/bar, with a high NaCl rejection of 94.8% (a). The higher water permeance is a result of the enhanced hydrophilicity (b), as well as the rough surface and a more crumpled PA layer, which increases the effective surface area (d). Beyond the optimal MOF loading, the lower water permeance of the TFC-CM (TFC-CM8) membrane may be due to the aggregation of NH2-MIL-53­(Al) on the substrate, which decreases the porosity of the substrate (Figure S2e in the Supporting Information).

elements.content: The membrane stability is important for water desalination applications. To study the membrane stability of TFC membranes containing CNFs and NH2-MIL-53­(Al) particles, the water permeance and NaCl rejection were measured over the operating time (b). As shown in b, with the exception of a small fluctuation at the initial stage, both the salt rejection and water permeance of the TFC-CM4 membrane remain stable throughout the experiment. This demonstrates the stability of TFC-CM4 membrane performance, which can be attributed to the covalent bonding between the NH2-MIL-53­(Al) particles and PA networks, as the amino groups of NH2-MIL-53­(Al) may react with TMC during the membrane formation. This may be proved by the FTIR spectra of TFC-Nylon and TFC-CM4 membranes (a). Compared with the TFC-Nylon membrane, the peak at 1656 cm–1 (corresponding to the C–N stretching) of the TFC-CM4 membrane is more prominent.

elements.content: The CNF/NH2-MIL-53­(Al)-loaded TFC membranes enable a hilly and hydrophilic PA nanofilm that improves the membrane separation performance compared to the commercial TFC RO membrane coupons (the DOW BW30 and GE AG membranes) tested under the same testing condition in our laboratory (c). The water permeance values of the DOW BW30 and GE AG membranes are 3.53 and 2.35 LMH/bar, respectively, while the salt rejection values are 95.9 and 92.3%, respectively. The CNF/NH2-MIL-53­(Al)-loaded TFC RO membrane (TFC-CM4) shows >50% greater water permeance than the commercial RO membranes with similar monovalent salt rejection.

The water permeance values of the DOW BW30 and GE AG membranes are 3.53 and 2.35 LMH/bar, respectively, while the salt rejection values are 95.9 and 92.3%, respectively. The CNF/NH2-MIL-53(Al)-loaded TFC RO membrane (TFC-CM4) shows >50% greater water permeance than the commercial RO membranes with similar monovalent salt rejection.

elements.content: In summary, we have developed an effective strategy to fabricate high-performance TFC RO membrane by designing a new substrate structure. The CNF/NH2-MIL-53­(Al)-loaded Nylon membrane was used as the substrate for the formation of a thin and more hydrophilic polyamide layer with a hilly surface via interfacial polymerization. This substrate modification method is facile and effective for synthesizing the hilly TFC membranes with enhanced desalination performance. The ability to produce stable and very hilly TFC membranes based on nanofibers and MOFs opens a new avenue to fabricate TFC RO membranes with desirable properties.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we have developed an effective strategy to fabricate high-performance TFC RO membrane by designing a new substrate structure. The CNF/NH2-MIL-53(Al)-loaded Nylon membrane was used as the substrate for the formation of a thin and more hydrophilic polyamide layer with a hilly surface via interfacial polymerization. This substrate modification method is facile and effective for synthesizing the hilly TFC membranes with enhanced desalination performance. The ability to produce stable and very hilly TFC membranes based on nanofibers and MOFs opens a new avenue to fabricate TFC RO membranes with desirable properties.

elements.content: Nylon membrane filters (0.1 μm, 47 mm) were purchased from Sterlitech. Sodium bromide (99%), 2,2,6,6-tetramethyl-1-piperidinyloxy (TEMPO, 98%), hydrochloric acid (37%), a sodium hypochlorite (NaClO) solution (12.5 w/v %), 2-aminoterephthalic acid (NH2-BDC), aluminum­(III) nitrate nanohydrate (Al­(NO3)3·9H2O), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), trimesoyl chloride (TMC, 98%), m-phenylenediamine (MPD, 99%), caprolactam (99%), and hexane (95%) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Sodium hydroxide (99%), ethanol (99%), and sodium chloride (99%) were supplied by Merck Pty Ltd. The kraft pulp (cellulose, Kinleith Hi White) was kindly provided by Oji Fibre Solutions Company. Mill-Q water (18.2 MΩ·cm, Millipore) was used in the experiments.
elements.clean_text:
Methods

Materials

Nylon membrane filters (0.1 μm, 47 mm) were purchased from Sterlitech. Sodium bromide (99%), 2,2,6,6-tetramethyl-1-piperidinyloxy (TEMPO, 98%), hydrochloric acid (37%), a sodium hypochlorite (NaClO) solution (12.5 w/v %), 2-aminoterephthalic acid (NH2-BDC), aluminum(III) nitrate nanohydrate (Al(NO3)3⋅9H2O), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), trimesoyl chloride (TMC, 98%), m-phenylenediamine (MPD, 99%), caprolactam (99%), and hexane (95%) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Sodium hydroxide (99%), ethanol (99%), and sodium chloride (99%) were supplied by Merck Pty Ltd. The kraft pulp (cellulose, Kinleith Hi White) was kindly provided by Oji Fibre Solutions Company. Mill-Q water (18.2 MΩ⋅cm, Millipore) was used in the experiments.

elements.content: The synthesis method of a CNF suspension solution was described in our previous work. Briefly, 100 mg of NaBr and 16 mg of TEMPO were added in 100 mL of a kraft pulp solution (0.01 g/ml), followed by adding 11.16 g of a NaClO solution. The pH of the above solution was adjusted at 10 by adding a 0.1M HCl solution and a 0.5M NaOH solution. The reaction continued for 8 h and was terminated by adding 5 mL of ethanol. The solid was collected by centrifugation at 8000 rpm for 15 min, followed by washing with Mill-Q water. The solid sample (fiber gel) was washed three times. Subsequently, a total of 500 mL of Mill-Q water was added to the fiber gel to lower the fiber concentration to 2 mg/mL. The fiber suspension was vigorously agitated for 3 min using a Nutribullet 900 series blender to produce a milky suspension, which was sonicated for 30 min using a probe sonicator (Qsonica) with a pulse of 25% and an output power of 500 W–20 kHz. A transparent CNF solution with a CNF loading of 2 mg/mL was finally obtained.
elements.clean_text:
Fabrication of a CNF Suspension Solution

The synthesis method of a CNF suspension solution was described in our previous work. Briefly, 100 mg of NaBr and 16 mg of TEMPO were added in 100 mL of a kraft pulp solution (0.01 g/ml), followed by adding 11.16 g of a NaClO solution. The pH of the above solution was adjusted at 10 by adding a 0.1M HCl solution and a 0.5M NaOH solution. The reaction continued for 8 h and was terminated by adding 5 mL of ethanol. The solid was collected by centrifugation at 8000 rpm for 15 min, followed by washing with Mill-Q water. The solid sample (fiber gel) was washed three times. Subsequently, a total of 500 mL of Mill-Q water was added to the fiber gel to lower the fiber concentration to 2 mg/mL. The fiber suspension was vigorously agitated for 3 min using a Nutribullet 900 series blender to produce a milky suspension, which was sonicated for 30 min using a probe sonicator (Qsonica) with a pulse of 25% and an output power of 500 W-20 kHz. A transparent CNF solution with a CNF loading of 2 mg/mL was finally obtained.

elements.content: NH2-MIL-53­(Al) crystals were synthesized hydrothermally with NH2-BDC and Al­(NO3)3·9H2O as the organic linker and the metal source, respectively. A total of 0.779 g of Al­(NO3)3·9H2O and 0.376 g of NH2-BDC were dissolved in 5 mL of Mill-Q water, and the resulting solution was transferred into a Teflon-lined steel autoclave (a total volume of 50 mL), which was then placed in an oven at 150 °C for 24 h. After cooling, a yellow solid product was collected by centrifugation. The resultant yellow powder was dried at 70 °C overnight.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of NH2-MIL-53(Al)

NH2-MIL-53(Al) crystals were synthesized hydrothermally with NH2-BDC and Al(NO3)3⋅9H2O as the organic linker and the metal source, respectively. A total of 0.779 g of Al(NO3)3⋅9H2O and 0.376 g of NH2-BDC were dissolved in 5 mL of Mill-Q water, and the resulting solution was transferred into a Teflon-lined steel autoclave (a total volume of 50 mL), which was then placed in an oven at 150 °C for 24 h. After cooling, a yellow solid product was collected by centrifugation. The resultant yellow powder was dried at 70 °C overnight.

elements.content: Different amounts of NH2-MIL-53­(Al) particles were added into the CNF suspension solution to achieve CNF/NH2-MIL-53­(Al) mixture solutions. The concentration of the CNF in the mixture solutions was the same (500 μg/mL), and the concentrations of NH2-MIL-53­(Al) were 0, 12.5, 25, 50, and 100 μg/mL, respectively. A total of 2 mL of the prepared CNF/NH2-MIL-53­(Al) mixture solutions was deposited onto a 12.5 cm2 Nylon substrate via vacuum filtration. After being dried at 100 °C for 20 min, the CNF/NH2-MIL-53­(Al) membranes with the same CNF loading (80 μg/cm2) and different NH2-MIL-53­(Al) loadings (0, 2, 4, and 8 μg/cm2) were obtained. The resulting CNF/NH2-MIL-53­(Al) substrates were denoted as Nylon, CM0, CM2, CM4, and CM8, respectively. The mass loadings of CNFs and NH2-MIL-53­(Al) are listed in Table S1.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of CNF/NH2-MIL-53(Al) Substrate Membranes

Different amounts of NH2-MIL-53(Al) particles were added into the CNF suspension solution to achieve CNF/NH2-MIL-53(Al) mixture solutions. The concentration of the CNF in the mixture solutions was the same (500 μg/mL), and the concentrations of NH2-MIL-53(Al) were 0, 12.5, 25, 50, and 100 μg/mL, respectively. A total of 2 mL of the prepared CNF/NH2-MIL-53(Al) mixture solutions was deposited onto a 12.5 cm2 Nylon substrate via vacuum filtration. After being dried at 100 °C for 20 min, the CNF/NH2-MIL-53(Al) membranes with the same CNF loading (80 μg/cm2) and different NH2-MIL-53(Al) loadings (0, 2, 4, and 8 μg/cm2) were obtained. The resulting CNF/NH2-MIL-53(Al) substrates were denoted as Nylon, CM0, CM2, CM4, and CM8, respectively. The mass loadings of CNFs and NH2-MIL-53(Al) are listed in Table S1.

elements.content: A piece of the above prepared CNF/NH2-MIL-53­(Al) membranes was used as a substrate and put in a vacuum filtration setup. The aqueous-phase solution (MPD 2 wt %, caprolactam 0.8 wt %) was poured on the Nylon or CM substrate for 30 s, and then the solution was poured off from the substrate. The substrate was left vertically in the fume hood for 1 min to remove the excess MPD solution. The organic TMC n-hexane solution (0.1 w/v %) was then poured over the substrate to carry out the polymerization for 20 s. The membrane was finally washed with pure n-hexane, followed by annealing in an oven at 50 °C for about 20 min. Finally, the TFC membrane based on the CNF/NH2-MIL-53­(Al) substrate was obtained. The membranes are referred to as TFC-CM0, TFC-CM2, TFC-CM4, and TFC-CM8, respectively. A control TFC-Nylon membrane was prepared directly on the Nylon substrate using the same procedure.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of PA Membranes on CNF/NH2-MIL-53(Al) Substrates

A piece of the above prepared CNF/NH2-MIL-53(Al) membranes was used as a substrate and put in a vacuum filtration setup. The aqueous-phase solution (MPD 2 wt %, caprolactam 0.8 wt %) was poured on the Nylon or CM substrate for 30 s, and then the solution was poured off from the substrate. The substrate was left vertically in the fume hood for 1 min to remove the excess MPD solution. The organic TMC n-hexane solution (0.1 w/v %) was then poured over the substrate to carry out the polymerization for 20 s. The membrane was finally washed with pure n-hexane, followed by annealing in an oven at 50 °C for about 20 min. Finally, the TFC membrane based on the CNF/NH2-MIL-53(Al) substrate was obtained. The membranes are referred to as TFC-CM0, TFC-CM2, TFC-CM4, and TFC-CM8, respectively. A control TFC-Nylon membrane was prepared directly on the Nylon substrate using the same procedure.

elements.content: The surface and cross-sectional morphologies of the composite membranes were observed using a field emission scanning electron microscope (FEI Magellan 400 FEGSEM). The functional groups of the CNFs, NH2-MIL-53­(Al), and membranes were analyzed by attenuated total reflectance-Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (ATR-FTIR, Nicolet iS10, Thermo Fisher). The actual surface area of TFC membranes was analyzed by AFM software (NanoScope Analysis 1.5). The water contact angle of the membrane was measured using a video contact angle goniometer (Dataphysics OCA15, Germany) via the sessile drop method to characterize the surface hydrophilicity. At least five measurements were performed to obtain an average contact angle value for each membrane sample. The X-ray diffraction (XRD, Rigaku Miniflex 600) patterns were determined at 40 kV and 25 mA. The surface roughness and the morphology of the membranes were observed by atomic force microscopy (AFM, Bruker Dimension Icon).
elements.clean_text:
Characterization

The surface and cross-sectional morphologies of the composite membranes were observed using a field emission scanning electron microscope (FEI Magellan 400 FEGSEM). The functional groups of the CNFs, NH2-MIL-53(Al), and membranes were analyzed by attenuated total reflectance-Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (ATR-FTIR, Nicolet iS10, Thermo Fisher). The actual surface area of TFC membranes was analyzed by AFM software (NanoScope Analysis 1.5). The water contact angle of the membrane was measured using a video contact angle goniometer (Dataphysics OCA15, Germany) via the sessile drop method to characterize the surface hydrophilicity. At least five measurements were performed to obtain an average contact angle value for each membrane sample. The X-ray diffraction (XRD, Rigaku Miniflex 600) patterns were determined at 40 kV and 25 mA. The surface roughness and the morphology of the membranes were observed by atomic force microscopy (AFM, Bruker Dimension Icon).

elements.content: Membrane permeance and salt rejection were evaluated using a homemade cross-flow device with an effective area of 7.1 cm2. The operating conditions for all PA membranes used a 2000 ppm NaCl solution as the feed at room temperature and 15 bar. All membranes were precompacted at 15 bar for 1 h before the separation performance measurements. The permeance of the NaCl solution was determined by measuring the weight change of the permeate by a precision balance. The permeance of the membrane was calculated by . The salt rejection was determined by measuring the electrical conductivities of the feed and permeate solutions using a conductivity meter (Cond 730, inoLab). The salt rejection was calculated by . All results were averaged values measured from at least three samples for each membrane. P = Δ V A × Δ t × Δ P where P is the permeate flux (L/(m2 h)), ΔV is the permeate volume (L), A is the membrane area (m2), Δt is the filtration time (h), and ΔP is the applied transmembrane pressure. R = ( 1 − C P C F ) × 100 % where R is the rejection and C p and C f represent conductivities of the permeate and feed solutions, respectively.

Synthesis of NH2-MIL-53(Al)

NH2-MIL-53(Al) crystals were synthesized hydrothermally with NH2-BDC and Al(NO3)3⋅9H2O as the organic linker and the metal source, respectively. A total of 0.779 g of Al(NO3)3⋅9H2O and 0.376 g of NH2-BDC were dissolved in 5 mL of Mill-Q water, and the resulting solution was transferred into a Teflon-lined steel autoclave (a total volume of 50 mL), which was then placed in an oven at 150 °C for 24 h. After cooling, a yellow solid product was collected by centrifugation. The resultant yellow powder was dried at 70 °C overnight.

cln_elements.content:
Tailoring the microstructure of a selective layer is a highly attractive way to improve the water flux of a reverse osmosis (RO) membrane by forming a crumpled surface without altering its chemical structure required for high salt rejection. However, it is challenging to maintain its structural integrity and stability and high flux at high pressure during desalination. Herein, a robust hilly thin-film composite (TFC) polyamide (PA) membrane is developed based on composite substrates made of cellulose nanofibers (CNFs) and metal–organic frameworks (MOFs). Water-stable, highly crystalline, submicrometer-sized MOF crystals, NH2-MIL-53­(Al), are integrated with CNFs to form a robust and highly porous intermediate layer for the formation of a hilly PA layer. The resulting TFC RO membrane exhibits an excellent water permeance of 5.55 LMH/bar and a NaCl rejection of ∼94.8%. The strategy reported here has great potential for the fabrication of polyamide desalination membranes with enhanced flux and mechanical stability.

Herein, we report on the fabrication of a polyamide TFC RO membrane with increased surface area using the cellulose nanofiber (CNF)- or NH2-MIL-53­(Al) metal–organic framework (MOF) nanoparticle-modified Nylon substrate. The Nylon membrane has suitable hydrophilicity and high mechanical strength, which make it an excellent substrate to fabricate high-performance TFC membranes. In this work, we chose both CNFs and NH2-MIL-53­(Al) particles to modify the Nylon substrate. The CNF-modified Nylon membrane serves as a highly porous and hydrophilic substrate, and water-stable, submicron-sized NH2-MIL-53­(Al) crystals that are permeable to water are used to create a hilly surface morphology. The resulting CNF/NH2-MIL-53­(Al) PA membrane exhibits a high water permeance of up to 5.55 L/(m2 h bar) while achieving a high NaCl rejection of 94.8%. This strategy has great potential to be implemented for the fabrication of desalination membranes with enhanced flux.

The surface area and the roughness of the TFC membranes were investigated using AFM (c and S5 in the Supporting Information). Compare to the TFC-Nylon membrane, TFC membranes prepared on the CNF/NH2-MIL-53­(Al) substrate show much greater average (R a) and root-mean-square (R q) roughness values (c). The roughness values of the membranes increase with increasing the loading of the NH2-MIL-53­(Al) particles. An increase in the roughness value may lead to increased surface area favoring water transport, which may contribute to the increased water flux. The actual surface areas of TFC membranes with different mass loadings of NH2-MIL-53­(Al) and the commercial TFC membrane (DOW BW30) were calculated using AFM software (d). In this experiment, the projected area of each sample is the same, i.e., 25 μm2 (5 μm × 5 μm). The actual surface area of the TFC membranes is higher due to increased surface roughness, ranging from 35.4 to 62.3 μm2. As the loading of NH2-MIL-53­(Al) particles increases, the actual surface area of the PA membranes also increases. However, when the amount of NH2-MIL-53­(Al) particles is increased to 8 μg/cm2, the surface area of the TFC-CM8 membrane decreases slightly. This may be due to the agglomeration of NH2-MIL-53­(Al) particles on the surface of the CM8 substrate membrane, as shown in the SEM image (Figure S2e in the Supporting Information).

Desalination Performance of PA RO Membranes

The effect of CNFs and the NH2-MIL-53­(Al) loading on the membrane desalination performance is shown in a. Without the CNF modification, the pore size of the pure Nylon substrate (Figure S2a in the Supporting Information) is larger than 100 nm, which is not suitable for preparing a TFC RO membrane. Therefore, TFC-Nylon shows almost no rejection of NaCl and the water flux is up to 300 LMH/bar. Normally, the pore sizes of the substrate for TFC RO membranes are mostly in the range of 5–70 nm. The CNF-modified substrate has a smaller pore size (66.7 ± 16.8 nm) (Figure S2b in the Supporting Information), and the corresponding TFC-CM0 membrane shows a reasonable NaCl rejection of 88.3% and a permeance of 4 LMH/bar. CNFs have previously been used as an intermediate layer for the PAN substrate in the fabrication of TFC NF/RO membranes by interfacial polymerization. The PA layer formed on the CNF substrate contained interconnected CNFs imbedded in the PA matrix. It was found that the interfacial gaps between CNFs and PA could act as water channels to improve the TFC membrane flux. Our approach to the incorporation of NH2-MIL-53­(Al) into the substrate further helped to improve the NaCl rejection of PA membranes. One of the reasons is that the addition of NH2-MIL-53­(Al) particles can cover the large pores of the Nylon substrate (Figure S2a in the Supporting Information) to reduce the subsequent defects of the PA layer of the TFC membranes. Another reason may be that the additional −NH2 groups of the NH2-MIL-53­(Al) particles and the −OH groups of CNFs react with TMC, thereby improving the cross-linking degree of the selective layer of TFC membranes. The TFC-CM0 membrane without the NH2-MIL-53­(Al) particles shows a water permeance of 4.19 LMH/bar and a NaCl rejection of 88.3%. At an optimal NH2-MIL-53­(Al) loading of 4 μg/cm2, the TFC-CM4 membrane exhibits much higher water permeance, up to 5.55 LMH/bar, with a high NaCl rejection of 94.8% (a). The higher water permeance is a result of the enhanced hydrophilicity (b), as well as the rough surface and a more crumpled PA layer, which increases the effective surface area (d). Beyond the optimal MOF loading, the lower water permeance of the TFC-CM (TFC-CM8) membrane may be due to the aggregation of NH2-MIL-53­(Al) on the substrate, which decreases the porosity of the substrate (Figure S2e in the Supporting Information).

The CNF/NH2-MIL-53­(Al)-loaded TFC membranes enable a hilly and hydrophilic PA nanofilm that improves the membrane separation performance compared to the commercial TFC RO membrane coupons (the DOW BW30 and GE AG membranes) tested under the same testing condition in our laboratory (c). The water permeance values of the DOW BW30 and GE AG membranes are 3.53 and 2.35 LMH/bar, respectively, while the salt rejection values are 95.9 and 92.3%, respectively. The CNF/NH2-MIL-53­(Al)-loaded TFC RO membrane (TFC-CM4) shows >50% greater water permeance than the commercial RO membranes with similar monovalent salt rejection.
